title: Bioimplantable Device, 2004
medium:
Medium: polyester 
Technique: machine embroidered with base cloth dissolved
description: Bioimplantable device for reconstructive shoulder surgery with three tabs of different lengths projecting out in a semicircular form, machine embroidered in white and blue polyester with the base cloth dissolved for a lace-like effect.
justification: This embroidered medical device is an unconventional collaboration between physicians and embroidery designers, combining textile engineering with the life sciences. It was developed by Ellis Developments Ltd., manufactured by Pearsalls Ltd., designed by Prof. Simon Frostick, Dr. Lars Neumann, Prof. W. Angus Wallace, and Dr. Alan McLeod between 1997 and 2003, and the textile was designed by Peter Butcher in England in 2004. The technique of machine embroidery on dissolvable substrate, long used to produce machine-made lace, is employed here to embroider surgical devices from suture thread. The CAD program used to create new embroidery designs is used in conjunction with advanced medical imaging technologies to create customized implants which mimic natural fibrous arrays like ligaments. The device is manufactured in the form of a snowflake, with eight short and eight long projections from a center ring, machine embroidered in white and blue polyester with the base cloth dissolved for a lace-like effect. The embroidery technique allows the creation of “structurally biocompatible” devices with integrated eyelets for the insertion of screws and an open lace-like structure that promotes tissue in-growth.

tombstone.epitaph:
Bioimplantable Device, 2004.
2004. Medium: polyester 
Technique: machine embroidered with base cloth dissolved. Gift of Ellis Developments Ltd.. 2004-15-3.
